citations.narrative:
Currently the otters are rotated through two different pools and given access to submerge and swim every three to four
days. The remaining time, they are housed in enclosures that provide a nest box and a ledge to climb on, but no water
source for submerging/swimming. As a semi aquatic species, swimming is a normal postural and social adjustment for
this species. Not having access to water limits their freedom of movement and can contribute to stress or abnormal
behavior patterns. The licensee stated that sometimes the otters will begin to self-mutilate and have a hard time stopping.
A female recently rejected her own pups, eating two of them. These are indicators of stress which may be exacerbated
due to lack of a water source that allows for normal postural movement. Animals that are semi aquatic in nature should
have enclosures that provide sufficient space for these behaviors for their health and well-being. Correct by: May 10, 2023

There is an accumulation of feces in most enclosures that needs to be removed more frequently. Accumulations of
excreta may harbor pathogens which may be harmful to the otters. Enclosures should be cleaned as often as necessary
to minimize disease hazards for the overall health of the otters. Correct by April 23, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Lauren Murphy, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
